div.p: 1. IV. Saturday.

With the month I commenced a course of occupation, in which, I can only enjoin upon myself to persevere— Rising at four O’Clock I wrote, after preparation for the day till about Sunrise. Then took my accustomed walk— Received by the mail a Letter from my Son Charles written at Boston, last Tuesday; and one to W. S. Smith from his wife, at Quincy, of the same date— I may cherish the hope that the health of my dear wife may yet be to a great degree restored— I resumed the writing of the Discourse upon the life and character of La Fayette— Dr Huntt was here to see Mary, who seems to be gaining strength— Judge Cranch visited me, and I had conversation with him concerning the taking out Letters of Administration, upon the Estate of my Son John, and of Guardianship of his two children— Upon full deliberation I believe it will be necessary— W. S. Smith dined with me— I invited him to do so every day, till his wife comes home, but he declined. I answered a Letter from J. R. M. Bryant, the tenant of one of my houses; and also, my Son Charles’s Letter— To effect this, I had very little time to read, and was obliged to write all the Evening till 9 O’Clock— I return this Night to my Bed-chamber.
2. IV:30 Sunday.

On returning from my usual morning walk, I found a Letter from my Son Charles which I answered— It made a deep impression upon my mind; his opinion of my condition corresponds but too closely with my own— I attended the morning service at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read Prayers for the 23d. Sunday after Trinity, and preached a short Sermon from Hebrews 7.24. “But this man because he continueth ever, hath an unchangeable priesthood.”— It was an exposition of the Calvinistic doctrine of the Story of Melchisedek, the most mysterious of all the types of Christ— Three verses in the 14th. Chapter of the Book of Genesis contain the whole history of this person as related in the Old Testament— He is named with an obscure allusion in Psalm. 110.4. but the Commentary of Saint Paul, in the whole of this 7th. chapter of the Epistle to the Hebrews, upon those two passages, gives them great solemnity, and high importance to the system of Christianity— St. Paul uses them with his accustomed power of Eloquence to argue the abolition of the Levitical Priesthood, and the consequent superseding of the Mosaic Law— Mr Hawley’s auditory was exceedingly thin, but the President was there, looking as well as I ever saw him— After dinner I attended at the Presbyterian Church— Mr Smith preached from Galatians 6.15. “For in Christ Jesus, neither circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision, but a new creature.” The doctrine of regeneration. Mr Smith treats these hacknied subjects somewhat differently from the common herd of Calvinistic preachers—he occasionally dwells upon principles of practical morality, and the virtues of social life— These are totally neglected by the generality of Calvinists, and even slighted by many of them— I met Mrs Meigs, the mother of Mrs Forsyth there— Mr Thomas Munroe paid me a visit after the morning service at St. John’s— I wrote from necessity as upon a week day, and finished reading the second part and began upon the third of a History of the civil, Military and political Life of La Fayette, in French— A book of those lent me by Mr Sparks.
3. IV:30. Monday.

I went last Night to bed with a heavy heart, and rose this Morning without having closed my eyes in sleep— The pressure upon my Spirits is greater than I can bear, and it is by the loss of Sleep that it operates upon my bodily health— What shall I do to be saved from ruin? not in the future world, but in this? I see no hand of relief from man— Shall I lose my trust in God? far—far be from me the thought—whom have I in Heaven but thee?— On returning from my walk, I received a Letter from my Son Charles which I answered— Several troublesome Bills were brought to me in the course of the day— Mrs Frye came and passed the day with Mary, and Mr Frye was here after dinner— I had much conversation with him, and finally concluded to apply for Letters of Administration upon the Estate of my Son John, and of Guardianship of his two children, to the judge of the Orphan’s Court— I devoted the morning hours to the Discourse upon La Fayette, and the Evening to the examination and assortment of the papers of my Son—with the intention if possible to observe this order for the distribution of time, until the Meeting of Congress.
4. V Tuesday

Grateful for a Night of sound refreshing repose—on my return from the morning’s walk, I found a Letter from Mr John Bailey, with a request that I would answer by return of Mail addressed to B. F Hallett or Henry Gassett— I did accordingly write to Mr Hallett Immediately after Breakfast W. C. Greenleaf came, and went with me to the Columbian Mills— I found the small mill in a ruinous condition with one side of the wall of the house broken down—at the large Mill nothing was doing— The Miller Speakman was there; without wheat or flour— I read to him the minute in writing but unsigned left by my Son, and by which Speakman had rented the Mills for one year from the first of August last— My Son had read it to me before I left this City on the 5th. of July and I had assented to it— Speakman admitted that it was correct, and professed to be willing to carry it into effect on his part; but it stipulated the quarterly payment of rent, at least at the rate of 500 dollars a year, and Speakman said my Son had told him he should not press hard upon him for quarterly payments— He talked also of repairs which he had made and which he said must of course come out of the rent. It is apparent that the man has nothing to pay, and nothing to do— He said he could get no wheat— That he had never known such a time— That the Mills of Lyons and Nourse are in no better condition— That they purchase wheat at 1 dollar 4 or 5 cents a bushel and must sell their flour at 4 dollars 87 cents a barrel— A clear loss of 33 cents upon every barrel of flour they make— I asked him what was the cause of this failure in the supply of wheat— He said it was the multiplication of Mills, and the readier Markets at Baltimore and Richmond. W. C. Greenleaf left me and returned to Georgetown. I went to the City Hall to apply to the Judge of the Orphan’s Court, for Letters of Administration upon the Estate of my Son John, and of Guardianship of his two children; but the judge was not at the Office, and his residence is at Georgetown— I called at Gadsby’s to visit F. C Gray and W. B. Lawrence, but they had both
left the city— I returned the visit of Sir Charles R. Vaughan, with whom I had some conversation— His health is precarious and he has been dangerously ill— I received visits before dinner from Mr Cazneau Palfrey, the Minister of the Unitarian Church, and in the Evening from Mr John Connell— A man named Miller came here, and almost ruffled my temper. He has taken possession of the vacant part of my lots upon which are built the two Houses in F. Street, and of the Stable— He says it was by a verbal agreement with my Son John last March— That he was to hold them for a year in consideration of his putting a fence there which he has done— And he has turned the ground into a vegetable garden— A man applied to Mr Frye yesterday to rent the Stable for a year at 3 dollars a Month— Mr Frye authorized him to deposit a load of hay in the stable, but Miller claimed the right of possession, and had a lock upon the door. The man last Night took a staple out of the door, and put in his load of hay— Miller said he considered it as burglary— I called upon him for evidence of my Sons verbal agreement with him alledged by him— He said his brother Doctor Miller would testify to it, and I assured him I would fulfil any agreement made by my Son— In the mean time he is not to dispute my right of possession of the Stable— My time thus engrossed reduced my writing concerning La Fayette to half a page.
5. V:15 Wednesday

A second Night of calm repose, and sleep undisturbed— I varied a little the morning walk and on returning from it, received a Letter from my dear and most afflicted wife which I answered— I received also a Letter from a Committee of the whig young men of Boston, enclosing a Resolution passed by them at a public Meeting, approving of my conduct in Congress and of my approbation of the Administration of the State. I had a morning visit from Sir Charles R. Vaughan, interrupted by one from Mr Charles Delavan of Albany with Dr Sewall— Mr Delavan is much devoted to the cause of the Temperance Reform, which now agitates the community— He said he was going to Europe, on some purpose connected with this object, and he had obtained the signatures of James Madison and of President Andrew Jackson, recommending to the young men of the United States, total abstinence from the use of ardent Spirits, as a drink— Mr Delavan was exceedingly urgent that I should also sign this paper, which after some conversation with him I did—though with much reluctance— I observed that I had not joined any Temperance Society; though I heartily approved of their object, and wished them success in their cause— As the President of the United States, and the only surviving Ex-President besides me had consented to sign the paper, I could not refuse to sign it, without seeming to discountenance the Temperance reform itself— The paper purported only to recommend abstinence from ardent Spirits undiluted—pure Rum, Gin, Brandy or Whiskey— Mr Delavan said that was all that the paper intended— I then said my difficulty was the apprehension that the paper if published, would be otherwise understood— That I had all my life time been in the habit of drinking wine—generally with moderation;
sometimes freely— That I saw nothing like a prohibition to drink wine, in the Scriptures, but the contrary—a recommendation to use it moderately, and medicinally— I believed it conducive to health— I believed the same of ardent Spirits, diluted with water and in small quantities; and must not be understood as recommending a total abstinence from them— He said that Mr Madison had made similar remarks, and said he was in the daily habit of drinking a small portion of Toddy— I signed the Paper, and said to Dr Sewall that I believed the Brunonian system of medicine had made more drunkards than all the dram-shops on the face of the Earth— He said he thought so too— Mrs Eckardt was here this afternoon, and brought a marketing account with my late son—authenticated by her Oath before a Magistrate. Mr Frye spent with me a couple of hours of the Evening— I wrote a Petition to Judge Samuel Chase of the Orphan’s Court for Letters of Administration upon the Estate of my Son, and of Guardianship of his two daughters.
6. IV:15. Thursday.

I sent my petition to judge Chase of the Orphan’s Court, who sent me word in return that if he should be well enough he would be at his Office to-morrow— I called at the Office of the Franklin Insurance Company, and received the dividend just declared both on my own Stock, and that of my Son— I went next to the Capitol—looked into the House of Representatives where they were laying the Carpet— All the tables and Chairs being removed— I met in the Clerk’s Office Mr Horace Everett, who is here upon the Post-Office Committee of the House. In the Library, I took out La Cretelles History of the French Revolution, and a Volume by Lerminier, on the influence of the philosophy of the 18th. Century on the Legislation and the sociability of the 19th. The title of this book which I saw upon the Catalogue excited my attention, and curiosity, and much of the day was eroded by a cursory perusal of it after I came home— Mr Fendall paid me a morning visit—and Mr Frye was here after dinner— He left with me a paper concerning the property left by Thomas J. Hellen, and had much conversation with me, about the distribution of it— He promised to go with me to-morrow to the Office of the Judge of the Orphans Court. Mrs Frye spent the day with Mary and her Son Thomas dined here— I settled the Account of Cripps, and was otherwise partly occupied with the details of the household— The consequence was that I failed in half my task upon La Fayette.
7. IV:30. Friday.

Morning visits from Messrs Whittlesey, H. Everett, and Hawes, members of the Committee of the House of Representatives, on the Post-Office, sitting here during the recess. Whittlesey mentioned that the Cholera was said to be at Baltimore in numerous cases; and that it was reported there were several cases of it now in this City— Before noon I called at Mr Frye’s Office, and he went with me to the Office of Register of Wills, in the City Hall; where we found the Judge of the Orphan’s Court Samuel Chase— I applied to him for Letters of
Administration upon the Estate of my Son John, and of Guardianship of his two infant daughters Mary Louisa and Georgiana Frances— He made some enquiries respecting the amount of property left, and to which the children will be entitled, and fixed the penalty of the Administration bond, at 4000 dollars and that of the guardianship of each of the children at 7200. but he said he must see the children, before he could grant the Letters of Guardianship, and he required two sureties upon each of the bonds— He said he would call at my house and see Fanny, and when Mary-Louisa should come, would again come and see her— He enquired who I would name as appraisers of the Estate upon the inventory to be returned— I named Mr Thomas Munroe, and Mr Richard Cutts, to whom he agreed— The Register Mr Neal, gave me the Bonds made out, and I took them home, where I executed them with Mr Frye, and Mary as sureties and Walter Hellen signed them as witness— General Macomb spent an hour with me this Evening— I received and answered a Letter from Charles, and could get through only a part upon La Fayette, of my daily task.
8. IV. Saturday.

Anxiety, care, and affliction, present suffering, and anticipation of the future prey upon my Spirits, and affect my health, in a way over which my will has no controul—by the loss of Sleep— I have not an average of five hours of it every Night— I awake almost invariably before three, and rise between four and five— This morning I rose at four— I take the morning walk round the Capitol; but find it not sufficient exercise for the day— I had Morning visits from Commodores Morris and Rodgers. Mr and Mrs and Thomas J. Frye dined with us. The Misses Cottringer were here in the afternoon and W. S. Smith also in the Evening— Borland the Carpenter was here, and spoke of an old horse that my Son had left with him, and which he wishes to return— There was at five O’Clock this afternoon an ascension in a balloon by a man named Parker, for the benefit of another by the name of Ash, who is sick. The enclosure within which the balloon was inflated is in front of our house, and we saw the ascension from our chamber windows— It was successful, but the moment of departure fixed at four O’Clock in the afternoon, was in fact but ten minutes before five. The balloon went in a Southeastern direction, and at five O’Clock I had lost sight of it. There were Artificial fireworks in the Evening, within the same enclosure, exhibited by a man named Scott, and which we also saw from the Nursery chamber windows. My daily task, was somewhat affected by these incidents, but much more in reading La Cretelle’s History of the Legislative Assembly— This History was published in 1824 and 1825 during the reigns of Louis the 18th. and Charles the 10th. in the high triumph of the Restoration— It is accordingly Royalist to the quick, and in no wise favourable to La Fayette—but it furnishes facts— It tells a horrible tale, and gives me a fit of melancholy as I read it— What may be more untoward is that it abridged my writing again to less than a page.
9. IV. Sunday.

Another almost sleepless Night and dispirited day— In the morning I attended with Walter Hellen and my Grand-child Georgiana Frances at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Smith from Ephesians 3.17.— “That Christ may dwell in your hearts by faith.”— And after dinner at St John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening prayer for the 24th. Sunday after Trinity, and gave an exposition of the 8th. Chapter of Acts, from verse 14 to 25. the offer of Simon Magus, of money to Peter and John, to purchase the power of communicating the Holy Ghost— There was nothing in either of these discourses that suited the temper of my present feelings, or that spoke comfort to my Soul— Between the services I read the 3d. Sermon of Henry Colman’s Volume—upon Christianity as taught in the Epistles; and the 4th. Directions for Understanding the Scriptures— These are popular Discourses; short and sensible, adapted to an unlearned Auditory, and presenting superficial answers to superficial objections— Edward Wyer spent the Evening with me, and consumed the remnant of the day— Mr Whittlesey of Ohio, and a certain Mr M’lean of New-York were in my pew at the Presbyterian Church; this morning
10. IV. Monday.

Scarcely two hours of sleep, and the rest of the Night passed in anxious and desponding thought, ever with the consciousness of the multitude of blessings yet left me, and for which no sentiment but of gratitude ought to enter my heart— Why must this Sentiment be embittered with incessant fear that these blessings too are, I know not how soon, to be taken from me— The resources of wretchedness are Stoic fortitude which is insensibility, and Christian resignation to the will of God— The first is not in my nature. The last I know to be my duty, but is not always in my power— Reason is no salve for pain— Loss of Sleep, like Sleep itself is involuntary— And it weakens body and mind— I received this morning a Letter from my Son Charles with cheering information of my wife’s convalescence, and that she intends to leave Quincy, next Saturday to come here— After the morning walk, which I take regularly every day, and hearing my Grand child Fanny read and spell, I made progress in the discourse upon the life and character of La Fayette— This is now not the least of my sorrows and anxieties— Under the Harrow as I have been and am, and shall be while composing it, I see it must fall short, not only of public expectation, but of what it might have been, had I written with a mind at ease— There are topics involved in the Discourse, which it will be impossible properly to treat without giving Offence, to parties of the most opposite characters, and the whole theme has been so often handled, and especially so well by Edward Everett, that it is scarcely possible to say any thing new upon it— Nor in the condition of my voice am I
without serious doubts of my ability to deliver it— Yet I am unwilling unless from extreme necessity to ask to be excused from the performance of a service so honorably conferred, and which I have undertaken— This is the day of the annual, and also of the Congressional Elections in Massachusetts— My Constituents of the twelfth Congressional District, have this day decided whether they are willing to be again represented by me or not— Much of the fortunes of my remnant of days depends upon their decision— I called this Evening to visit General Macomb, but he was not at home— I received a friendly visit from Mr Hawley— Excessive weariness, from my loss of Sleep made it impossible for me to read or write to any useful purpose, till I bethought myself, of continuing to file the Letters left by my Son—which occupied me till my bed-time, between nine and ten— Mr Johnson called this morning.
11. IV:30 Tuesday.

I was again favoured with a Night of repose with between five and six hours of Sleep— I cannot expect more— There was a moderate steady rain this morning, not withstanding which I took my four miles walk round the Capitol Hill— John Kirk sold at Auction the old horse, kept since last Summer by Borland— Six dollars and a half was the price at which the horse was knocked off, and Kirk disappeared for the remainder of the day— I went to the Office of Register of Wills at the City Hall, where Henry C. Neale the Register gave me the Letter of Administration upon my Son’s Estate, but not the guardianship Bonds, because the judge had not seen the Children— He said the Judge was again unwell, and had not been at the Office since the day last week when I met him there— He gave me also the Commission to Thomas Munroe, and Richard Cutts to appraise the returned Inventory of personal Estate; and the order of the Judge, that I should advertise my Appointment as Administrator, in one Newspaper at the City of Washington, once a week for three weeks—and the advertisement itself, ready written— I gave Mr Neale the Administration and the two Guardianship Bonds, and am to wait for the Letters of Guardianship, till the Judge shall have seen the children— I went next to the Capitol, and took out from the Congress Library, the 31st. and 32d. Volumes of Hansard’s Parliamentary debates, containing the proceedings on the motion of General Fitzpatrick in the House of Commons, for the interposition of the British Government to obtain the liberation of La Fayette—Madame Campan’s Memoires of Marie-Antoinette Queen of France, Madame de Stael’s Considerations on the French Revolution, and Thibaudeau’s Memoires of the Convention and the Directory— The Consultation of these books for facts reduced by one half the effective writing of this day— Mrs Frye spent the day here, and Mr. Frye and Thomas the Evening— Dr Huntt had made a morning call. The disappearance of John Kirk was a petty vexation, bringing close home to me the necessity of my own attendance to the very smallest details of the household management, and the precariousness of dependence upon Servants.
12. IV. Wednesday.

Mr and Mrs Frye, were to return home last evening in the Barouche, and Ball had brought it to the door, when John Kirk who had been absent since the Night before last made his appearance—took the reins from Ball, and drove them home— Mrs Good and Margaret the house-maid waited for Kirk’s return till two O’Clock this morning, but no sign of him was seen— They sent Ball to enquire after him at Mr Frye’s—he had taken them home safe, and they had not heard from him since— This morning about Sunrise he came home, with the horses, their legs badly cut, and without the barouche— His account of it was that as he was coming home from Mr Frye’s, opposite the seven buildings some part of the harness broke—the horses took fright and ran away with him, racing through the Streets until they were brought up opposite the Post-Office, with the Pole, and other parts of the Carriage badly broken, and the legs of the horses hurt by their kicking up against their broken tackle. A Mr. Bell of the Post-Office had helped him to disentangle the horses. He had put them up for the Night at a Tavern opposite the Post-Office kept by a man named Henley, and had taken the barouche to the Coachmaker Bartlett’s to be repaired, which he had promised would be done by tomorrow— Kirk insisted that all this had happened while he was perfectly sober— But he went away again after Breakfast, and did not re-appear for the day— Walter Hellen called at Bartlett’s, and twice at Henley’s tavern— Henley assured him that Kirk had been sober, but much frightened— I received a Letter from my Son Charles, dated last Saturday— His mother was to leave Quincy that day, and I hope they may be here by the end of the week— I walked this afternoon to visit Mr T. B. Johnson; but he was not at home— Called at Sir Charles R. Vaughan’s and left Cards for Mr W. P. Adams and Mr Buchanan— Sir Charles was just going to dinner— I had evening visits from Mr Connell and Coll. Watmough; and not withstanding the perturbations of the day wrote a portion of the discourse on La Fayette, and an answer to the Letter from the Whig young men of Boston.
13. V: Thursday

I was preparing to go to market this morning when I learnt that John Kirk was gone upon that service, having returned home last Evening— On returning home from my walk, I received a Letter from my Son Charles, written at New-York, the day before yesterday morning— His mother, with Mrs W. S. Smith, Wilson and his wife, and Mary-Louisa, left Quincy last Saturday—reached Providence the next day, and came in the Steamboat of Monday from Providence— Charles came from Boston, Monday Morning, and joined them at the boat.— I wrote my two pages on La Fayette, not without laborious effort, and a day much distracted, with petty and private affairs— Susan Emmott who has lived several years with us as housemaid, and had lain sick several Months, till she was removed this day last Month, came back this day, quite recovered, though looking pale, and I
settled her account according to her own Statements, agreeing with Mary’s, and gave her a check on the U.S. Branch Bank for the balance due to her, and took her receipt— A Mrs Young came here with her niece to make application for a part of the House on the Pennsylvania avenue, of which Mrs Doyne the Milliner occupies the lower rooms. She wanted them for her Sister Mrs Wineberry a widow woman, about to remove from Georgetown— I sent twice to Mrs. Doyne, who is in arrears of Rent, and whose verbal statements of what is due disagree with those upon my Son’s book— I sent for and procured the keys of that part of the House, which Mrs Doyne has given up— Till recently she rented the whole— These little Tracasseries are irksome to me, and unavoidably waste much precious time— The advertisement of my Letters of Administration was in the National Intelligencer of this day— Ball’s time expired yesterday; and I dismissed him— I took a second short walk after dinner, at the dusk, and gave the Evening to filing and assorting my Sons Letters—a work that will yet take time.
14 V. Friday

Rain— Steady and moderate in the Morning—heavy showers in the Evening. I visited the house partly occupied by Mrs Doyne, in the Pennsylvania Avenue, with the Coach-house and stable, all which I found in good condition— The child Fanny was unwell in the Night, and had a hoarse cold all this day— Walter Hellen left us and returned to Alexandria— After dinner I took my second walk. Called at W. S. Smith’s, but he was not at home, and at Mr T. B. Johnson’s with whom I sat half an hour— When I came home I found Mr Smith here— He said he had seen J. Connell at Gadsby’s; who told him a Gentleman was there who mentioned that he had travelled with Mrs Adams and her Company from New York to Philadelphia, the day before yesterday— We had some expectation of their arrival here this day— I wrote my daily portion; but no more, and continued filing the Letters left by my Son. I could not find sufficient time for reading— Spent part of the Evening with Mary.
15. V.15. Saturday.

On going out this morning for my usual walk I found a total change of climate since last Evening— A chilling brisk Northeast wind, and on returning home found the Thermometer at the freezing point. It began soon after to rain, which froze as it fell, and continued through the day gradually changing to sleet, hail and Snow— At half past three O’Clock my dear wife arrived from Baltimore, with her Sister Smith, our Son Charles, our grand-daughter Mary Louisa, and Mrs Wilson— She has borne the journey, exceedingly well, but is yet very infirm— Mrs Smith went immediately home— Mr and Mrs Frye, and their Son Thomas were here this afternoon and Evening— My occupations were somewhat affected by the event of the day— My writing abridged, and much of the morning was engaged in cursory perusal of Scott’s Life of Napoleon, with a view to collect facts relating to the Life of La Fayette— From the returns of the Elections in Massachusetts last Monday, the party now styling themselves whigs have succeeded almost throughout the State— My own re-election to the 24th Congress seems to have been with little opposition. [symbols]
16. Sunday. VI.

The ground this morning was covered with Snow, the surface of which was frozen, and glaring as ice— I could not venture to walk out— There was no morning service at St John’s Church, and I missed the opportunity of attending at church— In the afternoon I went with Charles, and heard a Stranger, read the Evening prayer for the 25th. Sunday after Trinity, and preach from Philippians 2.12—[“]work out your own salvation with fear and trembling. 13 For it is God which worketh in you both to will and to do, of his good pleasure”— This was a half way discourse between the doctrines of Salvation, by faith and by works— I spent great part of the day in reading, Colman’s Sermon 5 on the proof of Christianity Independent of the New Testament.— This resolves itself chiefly into the facts—the existence of the Books of the New Testament, and the existence of the Institutions of Christianity, particularly of the Sacrament of the Lord’s supper; and the solemnization of the first day of the week as a substitute for the Jewish Sabbath—and Sermon 6. on Human Nature— I read also several chapters of Scott’s Life of Napoleon— Mr T. B. Johnson called. Evening conversation with Charles.
17. V:30 Monday.

On going to the door this morning for my daily walk, I found it raining and the ground a glare of ice— The rain continued without intermission the whole day— It kept us all confined to the house, and I gave much of it to reading— A few chapters of Madame de Stael’s considerations on the French Revolution—a few passages of La Cretelle—and a large portion of the Memoirs of Thibaudeau— All these works were published after the Restoration of the Bourbons in 1814. and before the last Revolution of 1830— I read for the sake of collecting facts relating to the Life of La Fayette, but in retracing these events of the French Revolution, an impression of deep melancholy is the sentiment resulting from them all— The facts are a succession of deep tragedies; with a total absence of all religious principle excepting in Louis 16 and his Sister, the two most deplorable victims of the Tale— The horrible effusion of blood for five years from July 1789 to July 1794— The constant alternations of Representative Assemblies elaborating Constitutions, and Popular and Military Insurrections destroying them— The despotism of a frantic rabble, succeeded by that of an automaton soldiery—and the wild and wonderful rise and fall of a military adventurer, oppress the mind with gloom, from which the only resource I now find is in looking at the results which now appear, and which after all seem to promise and even to exhibit some improvement in the condition of the human race— This is my consolation and my hope— I made out my task of writing for the day.
18. VI. Tuesday.

John Kirk on his return from market this morning told me he had been informed by Mr Gadsby, that the driver of the Stage which came in from Baltimore last Night at Midnight, had mentioned that my Carriage was overset at the Bladensburg Bridge— After some hours of painful suspense, about 2 O’Clock came a man who had been sent from Baltimore, with an extra horse to bring on the Carriage; who said that the Carriage had been overset from the Bridge into the water—and that the stream was so much swollen by the rain and melted snow that they had been unable to get the Carriage righted and it was still lying there— One of the Horses belonging to the Carriage had died at Providence, and Wilson had been obliged to hire extra horses to bring the Carriage
here— The man went back with money and the extra horse to Bladensburg, and about seven O’Clock this Evening, Wilson arrived with the Carriage, which though much injured was not broken— Mr T. B. Johnson was here this morning, and Charles dined with him— Edward Wyer paid me, an Evening visit— Neither Wilson, nor either of the horses was hurt by the accident which happened to the Carriage— This as well as the loss of the horse who died so happened, that I ought only to have taken joy that it was not worse— How dreadful would it have been, if the family had been in the Carriage; which accident rather than purpose had avoided— I lament to say that the perturbation of mind occasioned by these incidents now almost daily occurring, depresses me beyond all reasons and reduces me to a condition worse than childhood—for childhood helpless as it is suffers nothing by cruel anticipation— I look around me for consolation, and find nothing but terrible foreboding. Yet in this state I am constrained to write— I did write and made this day no arrears.
19. VI.15. Wednesday

My Son Charles left us this morning to return home to Boston, which occasioned my postponing my walk round the Capitol Hill to the middle of the day. I wrote and gave him a Letter of directions for the disposal of part of my property in Boston, for the payment of my debts, and a power to transfer the stock that I own, in the New-England Insurance Company— Dr. Huntt was here this morning— The day and evening passed off, in a fearful looking for of judgment—a temper of mind becoming habitual to me, and from which I see no prospect of relief— Philosophy and Christian Resignation lose their hold upon my Soul— A superstitious Sentiment of fatalism usurps the place of my Reason, and among the terrors that it excites is that of losing my Reason itself— My present condition deeply calamitous as it is, seems to me only the early stage of others in prospect before me, and of which my own death is not the term— The extirpation of my own and my father’s race is the issue ever haunting my imagination. Could I familiarise my mind to reflect upon this Event, as not only probable, but in the ordinary course of the destinies of the human race, it would yet afford me no consolation— The extinction of families, is one of the most common processes of nature—why should I expect that mine will be exempted from the common Law? It is also the policy of Republican Government— With these Meditations I read and write upon the Life and Character of La Fayette— Upon this I performed my daily task— I read also in the Newspaper of this afternoon the account of the fire, which on the 16th. of October consumed the two Houses of the British Parliament.— This compendious process of fire is one of the most powerful auxiliaries of Time in sweeping from the Earth the vestiges of human intellect and human toil— And all this leaves to be solved the only question in which all my duties are involved— What am I to do?
20: IV:30. Thursday.

Resumed my Morning walk— After Breakfast I took my two Grand daughters Maria Louisa and Georgiana Frances to the City-Hall; and there, at the Office of the Registry of Wills, presented them to the Judge of the Orphan’s Court Samuel Chase— The Letters of Guardianship were then delivered to me by the Register H. C. Neale, and I returned home. I had called at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and taken the paper of
this day containing the advertisement for the second time of my appointment as Administrator upon the Estate of my Son— There is no probability that I shall live to perform all the duties of the Guardianship of these two children, if it please God that they or either of them should live to age of maturity— This consideration requires that I should keep and leave a faithful record of my proceedings in this capacity of Guardian, as well as in the Administration of the Estate— I finished my daily task upon La Fayette before dinner, and occupied part of the Evening, in assorting papers, and made out an account for Mrs Doyne— Mrs Frye spent the day here with her Sister, and her Son Thomas was here in the Evening— The performance of my day’s duty was still very imperfect, for I left several Letters unanswered— I should at least answer one every day— My reading was chiefly of Sarrans—and scanty.
21. IV:30. Friday.

I sent Mrs Doyne the account of her Rent made up from the entries on my Son John’s Books, and the receipts signed by him which she had sent me— Upon which she sent me back a statement of account in his hand-writing, but not signed dated 29. May last, charging half a year’s rent to 25. March and giving credit, so as to leave a balance then due from her of 19 dollars 50 cents— This reduced the amount now due from her, upwards of 100 dollars— This consisted chiefly of bills, for repairs upon the house I sent her the account rectified— Mrs Frye, Mrs W. S. Smith and T. J. Frye dined with us. Walter Hellen came up from Alexandria, and Mr Frye and Mr Smith were here in the Evening— I read several passages in Scott’s Life of Napoleon, and wrote though with much difficulty my portion for the day upon La Fayette.
22. VI.15 Saturday

Walter Hellen returned this morning to Alexandria— Mrs Bieler came to enquire about taking the House occupied hitherto by Mrs Doyne, and we discussed the terms with out coming to any conclusion— I sent to make enquiries concerning the tenant of the House, near that of General Van Ness, without ascertaining even the name of the man— While we were at dinner there came a man by the name of Thompson, with a Letter signed Scott and Willet—claiming compensation for assistance in saving my Carriage, when overset at Bladensburg— The Letter stated that my Servant had told them it was my intention to make them a preasant Wilson denied this, but said the men had assisted him in getting the Carriage up and out of the water— I sent Thompson a five dollar bill to be divided between them, but he declined taking it, and asked the return of Scott and Willet’s Letter, which I sent him, with word that if they were not satisfied with that, they should send me their Bill— I received this morning a Letter from Dr Waterhouse and was plodding most of the day over Walter Scott’s Life of Napoleon; besides which I read three Letters in the Telegraph, taken from the New York Star—Noah’s paper—written by
Jules Cloquet a surgeon who attended La Fayette in his last illness— They contain some interesting anecdotes of his Life, and some good remarks upon his character— I read further a Chapter of Thibaudeau— There is some confusion of mind, arising from this promiscuous perusal of writers so opposite to one another in principle, commenting upon the same Events—La Cretelle, Walter Scott, Madame de Stael, Madame Campan, constrasted with Thibaudeau, Regnault Warin, Sarrans, and three other biographers of La Fayette, lent me by Mr Sparks; besides the Abbe de Montgaillard’s History of the Revolution which I was obliged to leave at Quincy— I took two Seidlitz powders for the second time; wrote my two pages, and in the evening assorted a few papers.
23. V.30 Sunday

I attended the morning service at the Presbyterian Church and heard Mr Smith from 2. Thessalonians 3.5 “And the Lord direct your hearts into the love of God, and into the patient waiting for Christ” from which words, Mr Smith with much logical acuteness drew a fervent exhortation to piety, or the love of God, and as usual with him, he argued with his hearers, as with free and responsible agents— After dinner at St John’s Church, where I took my two Grand-children, the same person who had officiated last Sunday, read the Evening prayer for the 6th. Sunday after the Epiphany; this being the 26th. after Trinity and supernumerary— His Sermon was from Job. 19.25. “For I know that my Redeemer liveth, and that he shall stand, at the latter day upon the Earth 26 And though after my skin, worms destroy this body, yet in my flesh shall I see God 27 Whom I shall see for myself, and mine eyes shall behold, and not another.” The Preacher took no notice of the different versions which have been given of this passage, nor of the various commentaries upon it— He took it as he found it in his English Bible, and raised no doubt but that the Patriarch Job had revealed the mystery of a carnal resurrection, and of his own immortality, by the efficacy of a Redeemer, to be born two thousand years after his own death. The Church of England so understands this passage, and makes it a part of the funeral service— But if Life and immortality had been revealed by Job, how were they brought to light by the Gospel of Christ— I read the seventh Sermon of Mr Colman’s Volume, on the question how far our Persuasions and convictions may be relied upon, and the 8th on the moral Government of God— There is good sense in all these discourses; but it is scarcely possible to discuss any moral or religious topic in a space of twenty minutes. Mr T. B. Johnson was here before dinner— I wrote only one page
24 V. Monday

Ball came to me for a character and told me he was going with a Gentleman to Richmond, Virginia— I gave him as good a character as I could— Settled with Rachel her account for wages— Transferred at U.S. Branch Bank my Son John’s Account to myself as Administrator and sent useless messages to Mrs Doyne, and to a man named Blaney, who lives in the house that was George Boyd’s— In the Evening I spent an hour in filing family Letters to my Son of which there is a large collection, and I read sundry Chapters of Sarrans; and some pages of Barry C. O’Meara’s
voice from St. Helena— Wrote my two pages upon La Fayette, with increasing anxiety that this first sketch of the Discourse is not yet finished; and that of the private business with which I am burdened I have yet accomplished nothing.
25. V. Tuesday

My wife was again confined to her bed with a severe attack of Erisypelas, and Mary was, also quite unwell. Mr Blaney who for these three years has occupied the house that was George Boyd’s came and told me he was unable to pay any rent— He was to have paid eight dollars a Month— He pays seven— In the three years he has paid eleven dollars— He says he has been cheated of 230 dollars by a man who had engaged to pay for the board of certain workmen, who lived with Blaney; but he took the benefit of the act of insolvency—a very common way of paying debts at Washington. Blaney is an Irishman, now working upon the Bridge at 75 cents a day— He has a wife, and four children, and wishes to get back to Boston where he says he lived 5 years. Mrs Doyne came also to tell me she was very sorry she could not pay any rent. She is a very respectable looking person— An Irishwoman and a Millener— Mrs Frye spent the day here and her Son came after dinner— I read in the American Annual Register of 1829 and 30 the chapters upon France, and some pages of O’Meara— And I dragged through the writing of my two pages on La Fayette— I received and answered a printed Circular from Mr M’Coun and sundry other persons at New York, with a Prospectus for publishing a History of the rise and progress of the arts of design in the United States—2. Volumes 5 dollars.— They propose to each person to whom they address this circular, to engage to take and pay for five copies of the book— Their Letter is dated 10 November; directed to me at Quincy, with a request that I would answer before this day.— I answered that I would take one copy of the Book.
26. V.15. Wednesday.

I called this morning at Commodore Morris’s house in Georgetown, to return his visit but he was not at home— I left two Letters received yesterday from Mrs T. B. Adams, to her two Sons, midshipmen, with a request that the Commodore would have them forwarded— I then stopped at Mrs Smith’s, and she came and passed the day with her Sister, who was better than yesterday— Visited at Mr T. Munroes but he was not at home— He has recently received intelligence of the death of his Son Thomas, who has been twelve or thirteen years in the Russian Service, and successively an Aid de camp of the Grand Duke Constantine and the Emperor Nicholas. I returned home—read the remaining Chapters of the American Annual Register of 1829–30. some pages of Sarrans, and some of O’Meara— Mr Smith was here in the Evening; and Mr Bryant the tenant of the house that was Daniel Baker’s. He has just returned from Philadelphia, where he was called to the dying bed of
his father. His wife was confined during his absence, and he says was exceedingly ill though he was not informed of it, at the time— He paid me 200 dollars due upon his arrears of rent, and promised an early settlement of the remainder— This is the first symptom of the payment of rent that I have received since I have been here, and it surprised me— I finally wrote my two pages, after 8 O’Clock in the Evening— The day slips away from me inconceivably, and my work hangs like a Millstone upon my neck.
27. V:15. Thursday.

My right cheek began to swell last Evening, with a slight pain which continued and increased the whole of this day— I took nevertheless my usual walk this morning, with a sharp and biting wind— I rode also about noon to the City Hall—and applied at the City-Register’s Office, with a Certificate of W. W. Billing Collector of taxes; that at a sale of Square 592 in 1829. John Adams had purchased the Square, and paid the tax thereon— He had omitted since then, to take a Deed from the Corporation under the Sale— I had bought the Square of B. O. Tyler in 1820. whose title was by purchase from the Corporation— But James Greenleaf had a claim to it, and contested the legality of the sale, by which it had been conveyed to Tyler— The tax upon it being assessed in my name, I permitted the sale, for the sake of completing the title— Billing was here this morning with my tax-bill of 1833. in which I am still taxed for the Square— He said that James Greenleaf had attended the sale in 1829. and by bidding had run up the price of the Square to 400 dollars, beyond the tax for which it was sold— Billing had given the certificate of purchase as by John Adams, which would have vested the new title in him; but Billing now added in the certificate that John Adams had purchased as my Agent— I took the Certificate to the Register’s Office, and left it with Mr Hewitt, who promised to make out and send me the Deed— I then went to the Office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court, and took a Deed from George Johnson of Alexandria to me of lot 18. Square 231. which had been lying two years and nearly a half in the Office, I went then to the Office of the Register of Wills, and found judge Chase there— I stated to him the case of the personal property left by Thomas J. Hellen yet undistributed, and asked whether, I must return it in the inventory of my Son’s administration. He said he could not decide to whom any property belonged; that I should make a statement of the facts and he would then refer the law to the decision of the Circuit Court— I called at Lieutt. Wilkes; but he was not at home— Then returned the Visits of E. Whittlesey and Horace Everett, who spoke as if the investigations of their Post-Office Committee would end in no very satisfactory result— At the Library of Congress I took out the last two Volumes of the English, and one of the American Annual Register— I found that Coll. Watmough had changed his lodgings and that Commodore Chauncey was absent in New-York— I came home, suffering for the remainder of the day and Evening, with a swollen and swelling face. Warm foot-bath, and tumbler of balm-tea, just before going to bed; with a promise not to walk out before breakfast to-morrow Morning.— A desponding, dejected evening—but I wrote my two pages. My wife was better than yesterday—and received a Letter from our Son Charles, dated at Boston, Sunday Morning. He reached home the Evening before— I have got through the Discourse on the Life of La Fayette— But what shall I do with his character?
28. VI.15. Friday.

The pain in my face subsided last Evening, and has not returned; but I rose an hour later than usual this morning, and as I had promised, omitted my morning walk— Finished reading the New Testament, and read the Chapters upon France in the English and American Annual Registers for the year 1832— I received my Credential from the Governor of Massachusetts as a member elect of the 24th. Congress; but from the circumstance that no formal opposition to my re-election was made in the District, the returns from only a part of the Towns have been published— From the official return to the Governor and Council it appears that the whole number of votes was 3728. of which 3234 were for me, and 494 for others; a proportion more favourable to me than at either of the two preceding Elections.— For this I am duly grateful, as a manifestation of the continued good opinion of the great mass of my constituents— And I feel it as a warning to remember the great and manifold blessings with which I am yet indulged; and to rebuke in my own Spirit the ungrateful temper of repining— I had morning visits from Mr Gouverneur of New-York andMatthias, and I walked before dinner to the shop of John Kennedy, who rents a tenement belonging to Mary, and which he rented of My Son— There is a note from him due and an Account for Rent; upon which his Statement agreed with the entries appearing on my Son’s books— It was late this Evening before I finished the two daily pages upon La Fayette. In Kennedy’s shop I met Amos Lane the member of the House from Indiana, who had a large plaister upon his head, and told me he had been overset in the Stage, coming here, and been in danger of dying by loss of blood— Met Hawes of Kentuckey also in my walk.
29. V:15 Saturday.

Resumed my walk round the Capitol Hill before Breakfast, the habit of which has become a necessity, till the meeting of Congress. Morning visit from Persico the Italian Sculptor, whom I first employed for the figures upon the Pediment of the Capitol, and who just at the close of my Administration was employed by Congress to make two Colossal Marble Statues, emblematical of War and Peace to be placed at the sides of the flight of steps on the Eastern front of the building— He has been five years in Italy, executing this work, and has now returned in the Constellation frigate with the two Statues. He is very much satisfied with his work, but now wishes them to be placed, not where it was intended they should be, but in the Hall of the House of Representatives. Evening visit from Mr Phillips of Salem; and Mr Jackson, one of the new members from Connecticut, of whom there are three, in the places of Foot, Ellsworth and Huntington— Mr Phillips comes in the place of Rufus Choate, who has resigned and removed from Salem to Boston— Mr Phillips made some enquiries, respecting the usual manner of proceeding in the House of Representatives, in the administration of the Official Oath to the members and their
taking their Seats, and also with regard to the usages in visiting, by members of the House; all which I answered, according to my information and experience— I took a second walk before dinner as far as Kennedy’s shop— And I this Evening finished the first draught of my discourse on the Life and Character of La Fayette—which must be wholly written over again— I read to my wife and Mary the closing pages, and Mary immediately remarked that if any of the foreign Ministers should be present they would not be pleased with it— That is very certain and the hint is not to be slighted.
30. V:30. Sunday.

Walking round the Capitol Hill this morning I met G. Y Lansing, and G Chambers; members of the House of Representatives from New-York and Pennsylvania— This forenoon I attended with my Grand-child Mary-Louisa at the Presbyterian Church, where Mr Smith preached from 1. Kings 18.21. [“]And Elijah came unto all the People, and said, how long halt ye between two opinions? If the Lord be God, follow him: but if Baal, then follow him. And the people answered him not a word”— In the application of his text Mr Smith, observed that the question now to those who halt between two opinions, is not between the Lord and Baal—but substantially the same thing—between Religion and none— It is remarkable that in the old Testament there is not a trace of Atheism, as a creed— The fool hath said in his heart there is no God—but this is a solitary individual, no common belief— The question of all the exterminating Wars was between Religions—who was the God, and who the Idol— Mr Smith gave notice that he should administer the communion next Sunday; and that there would be preparatory services on Friday and Saturday Evenings— After dinner, at St. John’s Church, an Irish clergyman, read the Evening prayer for the first Sunday in Advent, and discoursed till dark from Jeremiah 17.7. [“]Blessed is the man that trusteth in the Lord, and whose hope the Lord is.” Mr. and Mrs Frye, and their Son Thomas dined and spent the Evening here. There was an Eclipse of the Sun, almost total, which began soon after noon, and finished after 3. O’Clock— The sky was clear, but we only looked at it through smoked glasses— Mr Silsbee, the Senator called upon me this Evening; and mentioned to me his intention to decline a re-election; and his wish that I should be elected in his place— I urged him not to decline, and told him that if he should not be a candidate, I should leave the Legislature to choose whom they pleased, but if he was, I would not suffer my name to be used against his, and would immediately take measures to prevent it— He persisted in his intention to decline, but seemed to have some doubts whether it would be proper for him to withdraw his name— I said if that was his determination, I thought there could be no impropriety in his making it known, and if he did not, I should expect he would be re-elected— The party with whose opinions he concurred, being stronger this year in the Legislature than for many years past; and I had never heard from any one connected with the party—a whisper of dissatisfaction with him— I said it was not the practice of that party, capriciously to drop persons in office, willing to be re—elected; nor was it the custom of the People of the State— I should of course expect his re-election, if he would consent to be rechosen, as I hoped he would— He appeared to persevere in his Resolution; but said he had spoken to no other person, on the subject— He spoke much also of the prospects of the next Presidential Election, and told me, that Mr Webster
to his certain knowledge had indulged not only the hope, but the expectation of being a successful Candidate for the Presidency at the ensuing Election— I said I had heard so, but could not believe it; holding his sagacity and penetration in higher esteem, than to be accessible to so much delusion— There is not at present the colour of a prospect, of any one opposition Candidate’s being even formidable— Mr Silsbee concurs with me in this opinion. He spoke of his lodgings here for the present Season, and says the charges of boarding here have been regularly increasing every Winter for several years— That two years ago he paid for a Parlour, dining room, and 3 bed chambers; with himself, Mrs Silsbee, their daughter and one other woman, 65 dollars a week at Gadsby’s, who now asks 80 dollars a week, for the same Apartments, and the same persons, and 5 dollars a week more, for an additional Servant— 2 1/4 dollars additional for every person invited to dine; and all the wines used to be taken at the house at tavern prices.— There are other boarding houses at more moderate charges, but none, at which it would be possible for me with my family to live at less than 75 dollars a week, for mere board and lodging— I read the 9th. of Colman’s Sermons on Man’s personal accountableness; and the 10th. on occasions of self-deception— Not so much time for meditation upon them, as I should have wished.

Day. I have risen between four and six—write the journal of the preceding day, and then walk round the Capitol Hill; an hour and a quarter— Return to breakfast, and thence forward the occupations of the day are a chance medley of time— Reading Letters and News-papers— Reading on the French Revolution, Napoleon Bonaparte and La Fayette— And finally as far as possible writing two pages a day upon the Life and Character of La Fayette— I have also now returned upon me at the last Stage of Life, the Household cares, and daily wants from which I had for many years been relief— They come back too with distressing recoil, and multiply anxieties more even for the future than for the present. I have as yet made scarcely any progress towards the Settlement of my Son’s affairs; but hope things have been put into a train to proceed— Let me remember the text of this afternoon, and hope.
